title: Sarong

  object_colour: multicolored

  physical_appearance: This is a batik sarong. It features a repeated pattern of large bouquets of European flowers interspersed with butterflies. The background of the batik sarong is brown and filled with dense motifs of white flowers. There is a slit at the bottom-center of the batik
 and the ends are frayed especially by the sides. There is no signature seen on this batik sarong.

  subject_terms_1: Peranakan folk costume flower (motif) birds (motifs) cultural diffusion

  subject_terms_2: Batik Ethnic costume Peranakan (Asian people) Motifs Culture diffusion

  subject_terms_3: Batik Peranakan costumes

  sgcool_label_text: The buketan design
 comprising large bouquets of European flowers interspersed with butterflies and birds
 is depicted on both the badan (‘body’ or main design field) and kepala (broad vertical panel) of this sarong.  Although only two colours are shown
 the variety and density of filler motifs enliven the overall design.  This batik comes from the family collection of Oey Kok Sing (1896-1966)
 the second in three generations of documented batik-makers in Pekalongan.  Her later batik designs attest to her virtuosity in technique and inventive colour palette.  Her repertoire of tiny isen-isen motifs (filler motifs within the outlines of the key motifs) in particular
 exudes a strong sense of artistic individuality
 possibly informed by modernist designs on European printed cloths.  Her treatment of floral bouquets is also charactertistic of the undulating and curving lines of the Art Noveau style that was introduced in the northern coast of Java by the Europeans.  This piece is signed “Nj Oey Kok Sing “.

metadata.physical_appearance: This is a batik sarong. It features a repeated pattern of large bouquets of European flowers interspersed with butterflies. The background of the batik sarong is brown and filled with dense motifs of white flowers. There is a slit at the bottom-center of the batik, and the ends are frayed especially by the sides. There is no signature seen on this batik sarong.

metadata.sgcool_label_text: The buketan design, comprising large bouquets of European flowers interspersed with butterflies and birds, is depicted on both the badan (‘body’ or main design field) and kepala (broad vertical panel) of this sarong.  Although only two colours are shown, the variety and density of filler motifs enliven the overall design.  This batik comes from the family collection of Oey Kok Sing (1896-1966), the second in three generations of documented batik-makers in Pekalongan.  Her later batik designs attest to her virtuosity in technique and inventive colour palette.  Her repertoire of tiny isen-isen motifs (filler motifs within the outlines of the key motifs) in particular, exudes a strong sense of artistic individuality, possibly informed by modernist designs on European printed cloths.  Her treatment of floral bouquets is also charactertistic of the undulating and curving lines of the Art Noveau style that was introduced in the northern coast of Java by the Europeans.  This piece is signed “Nj Oey Kok Sing “.
